history.content: EE 126 (Probability & Random Processes) and EE 127 (Optimization) are great mathy/ML courses that fit directly with your interests in both the AI/ML side of CS and in communication systems. EE 123 (DSP) might also be another good course, though it seems to be offered only in Spring.

children.subject:
It sounds like EE 123 is the course you want to take (obviously after 120). In the labs for 123, you build a fully-functioning image compression and transmission system in Python and get acquainted with the common digital communication schemes -- it's really a lot of fun. EE 121 is a class dedicated to digital communication (this sort of course is standard for EE majors at other schools) but hasn't been offered consistently for about a decade (at least). 

Obviously, 126 and 127 intersect with AI/ML very well, but they're not really focused on communication. I am a 126 evangelist, but that course is primarily useful in this context as preparation for graduate study of communications/information theory (and basically everything else in EECS, to be honest). 123 is much more practical than 126. Something similar could probably be said for 127.

just fyi 151 is a world of pain for no signal processing content at all. It's true that modern communication systems are optimized at the circuit level, but the same could be said of all of computer science (and most computer scientists never need to bother learning about circuits). I'd say take 123 and then take 151 only if you're interested in seeing how DSP blocks can actually be implemented on an ASIC or FPGA.

120, 123, and 126 should be good for what you like, as many people suggested. I also want to add EE 122 to the mix, which I haven't taken, but is a communications class. You may also find EECS 151 interesting, haven't taken that either but someone on 120 course staff said the following "A look into the lower level logic and circuitry that goes into the implementation of many classic signal processing techniques. Teaches either ASIC (Application Specific Integrated Circuits) or FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Arrays) through Verilog (a circuit-defined programming language). This class is critical if you are looking to optimize signal processing.". There are also grad classes you could look into, like 223 or 226A, but again I haven't taken those classes so I can't really comment.

history.content: I'm an incoming third-year CS major and I've been focusing more on AI/ML side of CS, but I've been gaining interest in EE from working on projects and clubs and such. I realized I don't really know about EE classes. I'm interested in learning more about communication systems, especially wireless devices. I'm planning to take EE 120, what else would everyone recommend? Sorry if this post is naive, just wanted to gain some info.
history.subject: Interesting EE classes?
